body:
You must then meet with the mediator to check if mediation is right for you.

This initial meeting is called a [Mediation Information and Assessment Meeting (MIAM)](https://www.familymediationcouncil.org.uk/family-mediation/assessment-meeting-miam/).

The other parent will need to see the mediator too. They can either come to the same MIAM as you or have a separate meeting with the mediator.

If you or the other parent want to go to [court]({app:urls:route:going_to_court}) you must attend a MIAM, unless [you’re exempt](https://apply-to-court-about-child-arrangements.service.justice.gov.uk/about/miam_exemptions).

At the meeting the mediator will explain:

- how mediation works
- the benefits
- whether it’s right for you
- the likely costs
- [if you’re eligible for mediation through legal aid](https://www.gov.uk/check-legal-aid)
- other options available to you

If you apply to court only authorised mediators can carry out a MIAM. Check with the mediator before you book.
cost: Average cost of MIAM per person
cost_description: Estimated fees may vary depending on your location and the experience of the mediator. Some mediators offer reductions if you’re unemployed or on a low income. It may also be cheaper if you attend together. If you or the other parent are eligible for legal aid you both will qualify for a free MIAM.
heading: Book initial meeting with mediator
